info.document:
California Legislature live updates: 'Sanctuary state' legislation heads to governor's desk Sept. 16, 2017, 2:36 a.m.

This is Essential Politics, our daily look at California political and government news. Here's what we're watching right now:

Lawmakers in Sacramento are in the final hours of the 2017 legislative session, and are now considering the final versions of the last bills on the agenda. Sweeping legislation to deal with the state's housing crisis is headed to Gov. Jerry Brown. Which members of California's congressional delegation are most vulnerable? See our ranking and dive deeper on the districts that will determine if Democrats reclaim control of the House.

Be sure to follow us on Twitter for more, or subscribe to our free newsletter and the California Politics Podcast. Also don't miss our Essential Politics page in Sunday's California section.

All updates 2018 election Ballot measures California Democrats California in Congress California Legislature California Republicans Congressional races Politics newsletter Politics podcast State government California Legislature Sept. 16, 2017, 2:36 a.m. Closely watched California internet privacy bill dies in final minutes of legislative session Jazmine Ulloa

California lawmakers on Saturday shelved a bill that would have required internet service providers such as Verizon, Comcast and AT&T to get permission from customers before using, selling or allowing access to their browser history.

The legislation by Assemblyman Ed Chau (D-Monterey Park) would have enshrined in state law some federal internet privacy regulations that were repealed this year by President Trump and Congress. The regulations limited what broadband providers can do with customer data.

The defeat capped a behind-the-scenes battle that pitted telecom companies against state internet service providers and brought other bills to a halt in the state Senate as negotiations unfolded over legislation that would have had national significance.

Most of the so-called California Privacy Act would have codified the repealed restrictions crafted by the Federal Communications Commission under the Obama administration.

But it also would have barred internet service companies from refusing to provide service or limiting service if customers do not waive their privacy rights. And it would have prohibited them from charging customers a penalty or offering customers discounts in exchange for waiving their privacy rights.

The bill had the support of former FCC chairman Tom Wheeler and smaller California internet service providers. Opponents -- which included tech giants like Google -- argued it was being rushed through the legislative process.

For internet service providers that are already complying with the former federal regulations, the bill would haven't made much of a difference operationally, said Ernesto Falcon, legislative counsel for the Electronic Frontier Foundation, a digital rights group based in San Francisco. But the influence of the legislation could have been sweeping.

"California is a critical state because you are covering a large part of the nation just because of its population," he said. "It sets the stage for other states to follow suit."

For now, efforts to implement the rules could move to the ballot box. A ballot initiative proposed this month would allow California consumers to know what personal information businesses are collecting, what they do with it and to whom they are selling it.

Latest updates Copyright Â© 2017, Los Angeles Times
